text: HARVEY SHINE, mid-60's, sits at a piano in a scruffy recording room, tinkering. We hold on his slightly sad, intense gaze. Just then a shaft of crude light illuminate him, accompanied by a knocking sound. From behind a studi window, JOHNNIE, a young rocker type in his 20's beckons. Harvey closes the piano lid.
Johnnie, unpacking his lunch and turning on various butto sits at a mixing desk. In front of him are 2 large TV monitors. Harvey joins him.
Put my score up first.
They don't want to hear it, Harvey.
I know, but I want to hear it. Put it up.
I'm backed up already, Harvey.
(interrupting) Johnnie, you were the one that was late. Just put it up.

Johnnie reluctantly presses various buttons. A `cheesy' commercial for a washing detergent plays. It i accompanied by a jolly classical score. Harvey looks on forlornly at his work. As it comes to an end with a flour Harvey lowers his head. Beat. Johnnie glances at him.
Listen, Harvey. Marvin wants me to present my ideas while your away.
Harvey looks up, confused.
Huh?
Look, I'm not doing myself any favours here, Harvey. But, I'd watch your back.
We hold on Harvey's tired, pensive face.
Harvey hurriedly exits the studio, catching up with a man walking to his car.
Marvin? Hey, Marvin?
Hey, Harvey. Shouldn't you be in London?
Yeah, I'm heading there now. What's going on?
Huh?
Johnnie said something about you wanting him to present on Monday.
Oh yeah, No, I was just thinking that, what with you being in London - you should stay a while.
What?
There's no need to rush back. Enjoy your daughter's wedding.
What?
Well, Johnnie can do it. I mean, he can pitch the Samuelson account.
No, I'm coming back. Those are my connections. They have been for years.
I know but... they've got new people running things over there. I think they're after something... (beat) ...different.
I want to come back. I should be there in person.
`There in person'? Harvey, nobody cares.
I have to stand behind my music!

They're demos! - They're already pressed. No one needs to be there. They're not looking for you, they're not looking for me. They just need a fucking track. (beat/sighs) Harvey, you haven't booked a top line in 8 months.
You got me doing triangle chimes for Christ's sake - give me something to compose!
That's what I'm trying to tell you! It's not about composition! It's different now!
Silence. Harvey looks at Marvin.
What?
Beat.
I'm back on Monday, Marvin. I'm coming back.
Beat.
(sighs) You got to land this one, Harvey.
What are you saying? (beat) Say it!
I'm saying there are no more chances, Harvey. (beat) Enjoy London.

And with that Marvin gets in and drives   off, leaving Ha standing alone in the car park. We hold   on his face - h tired. He looks about him, then down at   his raincoat dr over his arm. He lifts it and drapes it   over the other
Sound of interior airborne plane. The seat-belt `ping' chimes.
Harvey, seated in a crowded economy cabin, looks down fro the now extinguished seat-belt light. He looks a little h Reaching up to turn on the air, he knocks his tray - knoc his drink into his lap.
Shit!
An attractive middle-aged woman, seated next to him, look over.
(to a passing Stewardess) Miss? I'm sorry. I've spilt my drink.
I'll get you some napkins.
(to his neighbour) Why's it always me?
The woman, perhaps wary of the length of the flight, smil noncommittally. The Stewardess returns.
Shall I take that?
Thanks... And could I get another?
A whiskey, wasn't it?
Yes. `Jamesons', no ice.
The Stewardess heads off. Harvey mops himself up. He plac the small mass of wet towels on his tray and sighs. Glanc out the window, he then turns to the woman.
A holiday?
The woman looks over.
No. Business.
Harvey nods.
(feeling obliged) Yourself?
My daughter's getting married.
Congratulations.
(smiles) Thank you. (beat) She's marrying an American. But for some reason we've all got to go over to London. (smiling) I told her we had a perfectly good wedding system here.
(beat/expecting more of a response) They both work there, you see.
The woman smiles again, then looks up as the Stewardess returns with Harvey's drink.
Thank you.
Harvey is about to continue speaking when the woman interrupts.
I'm really sorry but I have a meeting in the morning and I must try and get some sleep.
No... Of course. I'm sorry.
It's just, I'll be useless - unless I get some sleep.
Sure.
The woman covers herself in a blanket and turns out her light, turning herself away from Harvey. We hold on Harvey from a distance, spotlit in a sea of darkness.
Sound of a commercial London Radio Station. A `phone-in' competition takes place.
A radio hangs from a mail trolley. KATE, mid 40's, dresse a green uniform, turns into the path of a suburban house. passes a postman - who nods his head.
Morning Kate. Looking lovely as ever. If I was younger...
Careful Paddy. (pointing to her cheek) Blushing! Is she up?
Oh yes.
Kate smiles before unlocking the front door.
Kate comes through the door, picking up a small pile of m off the floor.
(calling out) Mum. It's me - your daughter.
Kate puts the mail on a kitchen table. Just then MAGGIE, Kate's mum, enters in her dressing gown.
Hello, my daughter.
They kiss.
Have a cup of tea with me.
I can't, I'm running late.
Maggie seems to ignore this piece of information and head the kettle. Filling it up, she peers out the back window.
He's at it again.
(looking through her bag) Who? At what?
The neighbour. Barbecuing or something.
We see her POV of her neighbour busying himself in his ba garden. Smoke rises from a small garden shed.
I heard he's from Poland.

(pulling a small package from her bag) So maybe Polish people like to barbecue a lot. I'm leaving your prescription on the table. (beat) You know, you don't have to keep taking these - the Doctor said.
I like to. It makes me feel better. (beat) Its 8 o'clock in the morning. Who barbecues at 8?
(looking at her watch) I've got to go. I'll call you later.
Kate's mum sighs and turns away from the window.
Of course. Don't worry about me. I'll be Ok. (beat) Have you got that date thing tonight?
I don't know, maybe. (kisses her mother) Bye Mum.
`Time and tide', Kate, as your father liked to say.
Beat.
Was that from his terrace in the South of France?
Kate winces. Kate's mum looks hurt.
I'm sorry. That was mean. (beat/takes a breath)
Look, I'll call you later. (kisses her mum again) I love you.
As Kate leaves, Maggie watches her go. She sighs, before returning her attention back to the window. POV: The Neighbour enters his smoking shed and closes the door.
A busy High St. Kate moves amongst the throng boarding a
Close up on Kate's face gently swaying. She stands readin paperback, oblivious to the crowded bus around her.
Kate sits reading on a speeding train.
The Heathrow Express comes into the station. Kate disemba
Kate arrives at a booth. A sign reads: `PSA - Public Statistics Agency'. A West Indian woman, dressed in the s green uniform, stands waiting. She holds a newspaper, fol open at the crossword.
Aggie.
Morning darling.
Kate goes behind the counter and turns on a light. As the booth illuminates, Kate unlocks a door behind and goes in Without looking up from her crossword, Aggie follows.
Kate places her bag in a locker and takes out a pair of heels. Sitting down to put them on, Aggie enters.
Four across. A filmy layer on the surface of a liquid?
Kate thinks for a beat.
Scum.
Aggie giggles to herself and writes it in. Kate stands ju as another co-worker hurries in.
Sorry. Sorry.
She kisses Kate on the cheek and opens her locker.
Thank God you're my boss.
Without looking up, Aggie `tuts' and shakes her head. Oon decides to ignore.
Are we still on for tonight? Matt's definitely bringing Simon.
No.
Please.
Only if you guys swear you won't leave if it's not going well.
No way.
Promise?
Promise.
Seven down. Another word for `souvenir'?
Kate thinks for a beat.
Memento.
Aggie laughs and scribbles it in. Oonagh rolls her eyes.
Aggie, why do you bother? You just get Kate to give you all the answers.
Aggie `tuts' again and waves Oonagh away. Kate hands Oona clip-board and the two of them head out.
As luggage spews out, a dishevelled Harvey looks on. He s his case and awkwardly pulling it from the belt, heads of
Oonagh and Kate stand next to each other, interviewing returning travellers. Kate interviews an elderly couple. clear she's good at her job.
So you spent the whole 2 weeks in the Toronto area?
Yes. Our daughter lives there, see.
Ah. (filling in a form) So not a business trip then?
Oh, no. Unless you count grand- children as work.
(smiles) Some might.
Harvey comes through a set of sliding double doors, wheel his case behind him.

Kate finishes up the interview with the elderly couple, a turns to see an approaching Harvey in the distance. She registers his attempts to steer a wide berth of her, but matches his movements, bringing him to a stop.
Sorry, I couldn't just ask you a few very quick questions, could I?
I'm sorry, but I'm in a bit of a hurry.
It won't take a moment.
(starting to walk on) Look, I'm sorry, but I'm tired, you know?
Yes. I do.
Beat. Kate's directness, brings Harvey to a stop. He turn look at Kate. She smiles. Beat.
I'm sorry.
Harvey continues on, glancing back once more as he walks away. Kate turns to Oonagh and shrugs, before returning h attention back to the sea of arrivals.
A Taxi pulls away from the Terminal.
Harvey sits in the back with his phone to his ear.
Hi Suzie, it's your Dad. I've made it in one piece. I'm in a Taxi on my way to the Hotel. I guess i'll see you all there. Can't wait. Love you.
Harvey hangs up. He dials another number.

Hi, it's Harvey, Harvey Shine here. Just wanted to confirm Mike for Monday. I'm in London at the moment, but reachable on my cell. Which is... Well you've probably got it on file, but just in case, 917... Well you may have to dial an international code first, I'm not sure. Anyway, it's 917 749 7558. That's 917 74...
A sharp `beep' cuts him off. Harvey hangs up and looks ou the window. Cranes loom on the horizon. He yawns.
The Taxi pulls into the forecourt of a mid-market West En London Hotel. Harvey gets out and pays the driver.
Harvey approaches the front desk.
Hi. I'm with the wedding party. There should be a room for me. Harvey Shine.
The Concierge taps into his computer.
Yes. I have a double room for you.
Good. Has everyone else checked in?
I'm not sure, sir.
My daughter. Susan Shine. Or maybe she's already going by Wright. Susan Wright.
The Concierge taps some more.
No, sir. No one of that name.
Do you have a Mrs Pearce?
More tapping.
No, sir.
The Concierge looks at Harvey. Beat. Harvey shrugs.
I'll go up.

Harvey enters the room. He places his case on the bed, ta off his jacket and goes to the window. A roller blind is pulled down. Harvey tugs on the cord, t avail at first. Then suddenly it whips up, causing Harvey duck backwards as the flailing cord almost takes his eye Warily, Harvey steps forward and looks down at the busy street below. He goes to open the window but it is stuck. tries again - but it won't budge. He looks around the room, then up at the now fully contra blind. Tentatively he reaches up and pulls the cord to lo the blind a little. It slowly starts to unravel and unravel...and unravel, until it hits the bottom of the wi sill with a gentle thud. Harvey stands in semi-darkness. Just then, to his relief, his phone rings. He hurries ove the bed and retrieves it.

Hello? (beat) Suzie! Hi darling. Yes, I'm here. Where are you - where is everyone? (listens/Harvey's face drops a little) Oh...I see. No, I didn't realise. I thought the plan was for everyone to stay together.
Noticeably dejected, Harvey sits down on the bed.
No its...fine. I just wasn't sure. (beat)
So your mother has rented a house for you all. (beat) I see. No, no, don't be silly. I'm a big boy. It's fine.
Harvey looks around the bland room.
Home from home. (beat) Yes, I've got the address. So, I'll see you there. (beat) I love you too. Bye.
Harvey hangs up.
Kate, dressed for the evening, hurries along a street. He phone rings.
Mum?
Kate's mum stands not far from her back window.
What are you wearing?
Dungarees.
Oh, you're not!
They're completely in again, haven't you heard?
(lifting back the curtain) Oh, you're just being silly.
POV: A now bare chested Neighbour at work in his garden. Smoke rising from his shed.
Now don't be nervous. Just be yourself.
(smiling) Ok, mum. Thanks for the advice.
Oh, listen. I've been thinking about Greece for our holiday.
(frowns) Ok, Let's talk about it later. (beat) I love you too.
Kate hangs up and crosses a busy road.
Kate's mum continues to spy. POV: The Neighbour bends dow out of sight. On rising again, he sees Maggie at the wind and waves. Maggie flinches, before dropping the curtain.
Kate comes through the door. Oonagh sits on her own at a booth. Kate joins her.
Sorry i'm late.
Don't tell me... (makes the gesture of a telephone) ...your mother?
She's worrying about her new neighbour. Says he barbecues a lot.
Very suspicious.
(smiles) I know.
I got you the same as me. (off Kate's gaze) They're at the bar. He seems very nice.
Just then two guys approach from the bar.
Hey Kate.
Hi Matt.
Matt embraces Kate, then turns to his friend.
Kate, this is Simon.
Hi.
Simon shakes Kate's hand. Kate blushes ever so slightly.
Hi. (beat) You work with Matt?
Yes. If you can call it work.
(laughs a little too eagerly) Right.
Awkward pause.
Come on, i'm feeling small down here. Sit!
They all sit down.
Close up of Harvey's face under shower.
Harvey puts on a cream linen jacket, that matches a pair slacks. He looks at himself in a full length mirror. He l good. There is a knock at the door, just as his phone rin
Room service.
Harvey opens the door, as he answers his phone.
Just over by the bed. Thank you. Hello?
A young African man wheels in a trolley with a pot of tea some biscuits.
Shall I open this for you?
He heads towards the window. Harvey turns.
Careful!
Too late. The blind wips up - toggle hitting the young ma the eye.
Are you Ok?
The porter, covering his eye, nods, backing towards the d
Oh, yes. Yes, fine.
Are you sure? Here.
Harvey wedges a fiver into his free hand as he retreats rapidly. The door closes. Beat. Harvey returns the phone his ear.
Hello?
No answer. He sits down on the bed and pours some tea. Ju then his phone rings again. He reaches for it, knocking t trolley and the tea onto himself.
Fuck!
Grabbing a tea towel, he dabs his trousers.
From a distance, across a crowded Friday night bar, we wa our gang chat. It seems to be going well. Laughter hangs the air.

A cab pulls up in front of a posh looking restaurant. Har steps out, dressed in the same cream jacket, but now spor a pair of dark trousers. He looks like a bad lounge act. cab pulls away as Harvey turns towards the restaurant.
Harvey enters. Three young men stand to one side, chattin animatedly. On seeing Harvey, one of them looks up.
Harvey.
Scott.
You made it.
Yes.
Scott turns to his friends.
This is Susan's father, Harvey. Harvey Shine. (beat) Harvey, this is my best man, Josh Stillman and Pete Turner.
Hi.
Hi.
How are you Harvey? (glancing at Harvey's attire) Its great to see you.
Good thanks. Great. (sensing his gaze) How are you holding up?
Great. (turning to his friends) Can't wait to marry your daughter, really.
Laughter.
No... (beat) Is she..?
She's through there. She'll be thrilled you're here. I'll go and find her.
Just then Harvey's phone rings.
Sorry.
Harvey turns away and answers.

Yes. (listens) No, no, that's not right. I booked Mike. It's important. I spoke to him about it two weeks ago. I booked him. (getting flustered) Have you told him its Harvey. It's really important... (suddenly conscious of Scott's friends standing nearby) Just...Just get him to call me, Ok?
Harvey hangs up. And putting on his `positive' face turns back to Scott's friends.
Sorry. (beat) Always something.
Sure. (beat) What's your field, Harvey?
Oh, I'm a... (beat) I work in the music industry.
Wow. Doing what?
I'm a composer. (beat) Sort of.
Cool. What kind of stuff?
Oh, you know, for...commercials, that sort of thing. TV. (beat) Mostly background stuff, that sort of thing.
I see.
Slightly awkward pause.
Sounds profitable.
It can be. (wanting to change subject) You guys work with Scott?
Yes.
Oil, right?
Futures, yes.
Well, I'm sure that's pretty profitable too.
The guys smile a little too readily.
Sometimes, yes.
Harvey tries to smile back.
Well, I'd better find my daughter.
Absolutely. Good to meet you, Harvey. See you in there.
As Harvey moves off into the adjacent room, the guys watc him go.
Kate and Oonagh wait in line for the bathroom.
So?
He seems nice.
Nice? Nice like good. Or nice like dull.
Nice like how old is he?
Oonagh smiles.
Old enough. Your age...ish.
He can't be, he's looks like a baby.
Alright, my age. But Matt says he's very mature.
Oh right. Did Matt offer that up - or was that in response to you two discussing my approaching barrenness.
Kate?
Just then Kate's phone rings.
Don't answer it.
I have to. She's on her own. (beat) She gets lonely.
Just tell her you're busy.
Kate nods and indicates that the loo is free. Oonagh goes as Kate answers her phone.
Mum?
Harvey enters the room. He sees his daughter, standing of one side, with Scott, talking to some friends.
She looks beautiful. He takes a moment to just watch her. she turns in slight slow motion, she smiles on seeing her father and joins him.
Hi Dad.
Suz... (beat) You look beautiful.
Thank you.
Slightly awkward pause.
Give us a hug then, as they say in this country.
They embrace. Beat. Off Susan's look...
I know, I look ridiculous.
No. You look...
Like a bad lounge act.
Susan smiles at her Father. Beat.
I spilt something on my trousers. (beat) I've been doing that a lot recently.
Harvey looks over at Scott in the distance, sharing a lau with his buddies.
Dad.
Long way to come to see two American kids get married.
Susan looks at her father, a little irked.
Sorry for the inconvenience, Dad.
Harvey looks at his daughter.
Sorry.
Beat.
Have you seen mum yet?
No. They're here?
Yes. They're over by our table.
Harvey looks over.
Please Daddy.
What? (beat) I'll be good.
Just then, they are approached by Scott guiding some frie over to say hello.
Look who i've got!
Susan's girlfriends shriek with delight as they approach. Susan turns to greet them.
I'll speak to you later Suz. You enjoy your friends.
As Susan greets her friends, Harvey retreats.
Kate rejoins the others. Oonagh and Matt are standing. Ma has his jacket on.
(to Kate) We've gotta go. Problem at home. Baby-sitter just rang. Nothing serious.
(beat) But you guys stay.
Kate makes eyes at Oonagh, who shrugs innocently. Oonagh to kiss Kate, while Matt says goodbye to Simon.
(under breath) Enjoy yourself - you miserable cow. And turn off that phone. (beat) Are you working tomorrow?
Yes. Half-day.
I'll see you Tuesday.
Oonagh kisses Kate and heads off with Matt, leaving Kate standing slightly awkwardly next to a seated Simon.
Looks like we've been set up.
Yes. (beat) Sorry.
No. It's not your fault. I mean, I'm fine with it. I mean, I'm happy to meet new people.
Yes, me too.
Why don't you sit down?
Yes.
Kate sits down.
So you're Oonagh's boss?
Yes. (beat) Sorry, I'm saying `yes' a lot.
Yes. (smiles) You are.
They share a smile.
Do you want another drink?
Ye... (smiles) Sure. I can get them.
No, it's fine. What do you fancy?
I'll have another white wine. Anything dry.
Simon heads off to the bar. Kate watches him go. She allo herself a smile.

Harvey stands at the bar and downs a whiskey. Picking up another glass, he turns away, and with drink in hand, approaches a group of people standing around a table. As nears, a distinguished older man with a healthy main of w hair sees him and momentarily touches the arm of the woma standing next to him. She turns around to see Harvey approaching.
Harvey.
Jean.
Harvey turns his gaze to the white haired man and nods.
Brian.
Harvey. Good to see you.
There is a palpable sense of tension in the air.
(deliberately only directed to Jean) So our baby girl is really getting married. Who would've thought?
Yes.
Harvey you remember the Watsons. Barry and Jill.
Harvey turns to a couple, standing nearby.
(slight sarcastic tone) Of course I do. Hell, its been a while. I guess, not since Jean and I split up.
Hi Harvey. You look well.
Thank you, Jill. You're looking well too. Both of you. I guess you guys stayed in touch with Jean.
Awkward Beat.
Barry and I work together now.
No kidding? Insurance?
No. (beat) Property, now. A small portfolio down in Florida.
Real Estate. That's great. (beat) That's really great.
Awkward silence.
Well I think we should sit. I know Susan wanted us all seated before they joined us.
Sure. Good idea.

Everyone begins to take their assigned seats. Harvey is o the inside close to the middle. It's a bit tight and invo people getting up to make way. Harvey gets to his seat an just about to sit when his phone rings. Brian and Jean sh a look. Taking it out of his pocket Harvey looks at the incoming number.
Sorry, I have to take this. (picks up) Can you hold a minute?
Harvey makes his way back along the table, causing people stand again.
Sorry. Sorry.
Harvey walks away from the table.

Kate sits waiting. Simon has finally been served and turn from the bar with drinks in hand. As he does a young woma standing with a small party of two other girls and a guy, greets him. Kate looks on. It's obvious from Simon's reac that they know each other well. Just then Kate's phone ri again. She looks at the number and thinks about ignoring but in the end, reluctantly picks up.
Mum. You've got to stop calling. (beat) What? I can't hear. Hold on.
Kate gets up and moves towards the back-room.
Harvey stands on the phone.
(getting more and more flustered) It'll take two hours max. No longer. (listens) Have you told him its Harvey? Look, we go back! He'll tell you. Just have him call me.
Harvey returns to the table. Everyone is seated.
Sorry...
He notices his name place has been moved to the end.
(smiling/to Jean) Did you move me darling?
No, Harvey. I didn't touch it.
Dad. I moved you. I thought it might be easier in case you needed to get out.
Ok, sweetheart.
Harvey takes the last remaining seat. Brian stands.

Shall we have a quick toast to get things going? (beat) I'm going to save my big speech for tomorrow. (laughter) Dear Susan and Dear Scott, I just want to take us all back to that wonderful holiday we all had in Rome together last year and wish you `Salute'!
Salute!
Jean and I love you both so much. And we're so happy that Scott is going to part of our clan now. And so I say many, many, happy, happy years ahead. Salute!
Salute!
My turn?
Everyone turns to Harvey as he stands to make a speech. J then his phone rings on vibrate.
Sorry.
Harvey scrambles to turn it off, as Jean rolls her eyes.
Sorry, I thought it was off. (flustered he finally manages to stop it buzzing) Um, uh. (beat) To Susan and Scott. A great couple. (beat) Cheers.
Momentary awkward silence.
Cheers.
Harvey sits.
Let's eat.
Yes...
Everyone tucks in. Harvey sits slightly blushing at the e of the table, knowing he's blown it.
Kate hangs up and returns to the main room, to find that Simon has been joined at their table by the young group. bolsters herself before returning to the table.
Hi.
Hey. Kate. (beat) Sorry, i bumped into these guys and couldn't shake them. (turning to his friends) Everyone this is Kate.
Kate holds up her hand, before blushing a little.
Hi.
Kate this is Andrew, Melissa, Gwen, and Elinor.
Hi.
Kate sits down.
Sorry, I hope we're not barging in on your evening.
Kate shakes her head.
It was Simon's idea. How do you guys know each other, anyway?
Kate glances at Simon.
We don't really. We just met.
Melissa looks at Simon and grins.
A blind date?
No. (beat) We met through friends.
I see. I think we should leave you guys alone.
(a little too abruptly) No. (beat) Don't. Stay. It's fine.
Slightly awkward pause, broken by Andrew.
Hey does anyone know the cricket score?
England were all out by tea, when I last checked.
Bloody hell.
Cricket. Don't get it.
What? Men in white. Oh, I do.
Kate looks on as the girls laugh.

Harvey sits at the end of the table, looking on, as every talks animatedly around him. He eats his food and drinks plenty of wine. Up near the middle Scott shares a joke wi Brian. Just then Susan, who has been talking to the best turns and catches her father's eye. He smiles at her and raises a glass. Susan smiles back before returning her attention back to her neighbour.
Kate sits among the group. She too seems to be detached f the proceedings.
I heard that they did it in her bedroom, while she was away.
It was her flat?
Yep. He has his own, but was basically living at hers.
Ouch.
That is evil.
As the conversation continues in this vein, Kate glances Simon. He seems more at ease in this company.
The meal is drawing to a close. People have gotten up and circulating around the table and nearby.
Harvey stands at the bar. He downs a drink. Jean approach
Harvey.
Hello Jean.
(to barman) Can I get a glass of water please?
The Barman obliges.
You Ok?
(Downing another drink) Fine.
Beat.
Go easy Harvey.
(getting quite loaded) Why, Jean? Are you worried i'm going to embarrass you again?
No Harvey, I'm worried you're going to embarrass yourself. (beat) And more importantly Susan. This weekend's just about her and Scott. Nothing else.
Oh, you're good Jean. You're really good. You've always known how to make me feel shit, haven't you? (beat) You've always been so good at that.
I've had cause to practice.
Beat.
Tell me, Jean. Were you ever proud of me?
Yes. Sometimes. (beat) But you never listened.

The parties Jean. The fuckin' parties, where I would hear you - dressing up what I did for a living - film composer this, film composer that - trying to make it more palatable for your friends. I'm a...
(cutting him off) Don't Harvey.
Beat.
What is it you see in Brian?
Jean looks into Harvey's eyes. Long beat.
He doesn't talk about himself. (beat) He talks about me.
Harvey stares back, momentarily transfixed, before turnin away dismissive.
Go home Harvey. Go to bed and see your daughter get married tomorrow.
Jean walks away. Harvey stands at the bar. Susan comes in the room. She approaches.
Hi Dad.
Hey Suz.
Are you alright?
(upbeat) Yeah. I'm great. How are you doing? Enjoying yourself?
Yeah.
Beat.
He seems a good guy, Scott. You'll be alright.
Yeah, he is. (beat) I'm sorry, I haven't had much time to talk to you.
No Sweetheart, it's your weekend. It's no problem. You just enjoy yourself.
Beat.
How's work?
Great. (beat) Well, not great, but...fine. You know the usual. Triangle chimes.
Susan smiles.
Are you still doing your own stuff? You should.
A bit... Not so much.
Beat. Harvey looks away, then back.
Listen Suz, I'm really sorry about having to leave early. It's just bad timing. There's a sudden rush at work, you know, a couple of big jobs in at once.
Sure.

It just can't be helped. But I'll be there at the ceremony, at the really important bit. I'll be there to give you away. (beat) And then I'm sure Brian or your mother will talk at the reception. You know me, I've never been very good at speech...
(interrupting) Dad.
Yeah, Suz?
Listen, I've been thinking. (beat)
Brian has been a really big part of my life now for some time. And... (long beat) And I'm going to ask him to give me away tomorrow.
Silence.
I'm sorry, Dad.
The colour drains from Harvey's ruddy face.
But Suz...
Dad, I've hardly seen you in the past five years.
That's not true.
Dad, it is. Maybe a quick coffee here, or a telephone call there but no, you haven't been part of my life. And... (beat) And Brian has.
Beat.
You having to leave early this weekend. I don't know, it just seems typical.

One of yours?
